{{Use British English|date=October 2013}} [[File:Kollebloemen - Red poppies.JPG|thumb|Artificial "remembrance poppies" at a war memorial in [[Ypres]]]] [[File:Tower of London Poppies MOD 45158094.jpg|thumb|right|The ''[[Blood Swept Lands and Seas of Red]]'' exhibit at the [[Tower of London]] in 2014 on the 100th anniversary of the beginning of World War I which consists of 888,246 ceramic poppies, one for each British and colonial death.<ref>[http://www.bbc.com/news/uk-29642463 "Queen visits Tower of London poppy garden"]. BBC News. Retrieved 6 November 2014</ref>]] [[File:Field poppy - Papaver rhoeas (12190335083).jpg|thumb|right|The flower of the common or field poppy ''[[Papaver rhoeas]]'', on which the remembrance poppy is based.]] The '''remembrance poppy''' is an [[artificial flower]] that has been used since 1921 to commemorate military personnel who have died in war, and represents a common or field poppy, ''[[Papaver rhoeas]]''. Inspired by the [[World War I]] poem "[[In Flanders Fields]]", and promoted by [[Moina Michael]], they were first adopted by the [[American Legion]] to commemorate [[United States|American]] soldiers killed in that war (1914–1918). They were then adopted by [[veteran|military veterans]]' groups in parts of the [[British Empire]]: the [[United Kingdom]], [[Canada]], [[Australia]] and [[New Zealand]]. Today, they are most common in the UK, [[Royal New Zealand Returned and Services' Association|New Zealand]] and Canada, and are used to commemorate their servicemen and women killed in all conflicts. There, small artificial poppies are often worn on clothing leading up to [[Remembrance Day]]/[[Armistice Day]] (11 November).<ref>http://www.bbc.com/news/magazine-15637074 BBC News. Retrieved 14 November 2014</ref> Poppy [[wreath]]s are also often laid at [[war memorial]]s. In New Zealand they are worn on [[Anzac Day]], (25th April) in commemoration of the [[Gallipoli Campaign]].
==Origins== The remembrance poppy was inspired by the World War I poem "[[In Flanders Fields]]". Its opening lines refer to the many poppies that were the first flowers to grow in the churned-up earth of soldiers' graves in [[Flanders]], a region of Europe that overlies a part of [[Belgium]].<ref name="bbc10nov06">{{cite news | author = | title =Where did the idea to sell poppies come from? | publisher =BBC News | date =10 November 2006 | url =http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/magazine/6133312.stm | accessdate=2009-02-18}}</ref> It is written from the point of view of the dead soldiers and, in the last verse, they call on the living to continue the conflict.<ref name="fox">Fox, James. "Poppy Politics: Remembrance of Things Present", in ''Cultural Heritage Ethics: Between Theory and Practice''. Open Book Publishers, 2014. pp.23-28</ref> The poem was written by [[Canada|Canadian]] physician, [[Lieutenant Colonel]] [[John McCrae]], on 3 May 1915 after witnessing the death of his friend, a fellow soldier, the day before. The poem was first published on 8 December 1915 in the [[London]]-based magazine ''[[Punch (magazine)|Punch]]''.
[[Image:00MoinaMichael.jpg|200px|thumb|right|Moina Michael on a 1948 U.S. commemorative stamp]]In 1918, [[Moina Michael]], who had taken leave from her professorship at the [[University of Georgia]] to be a volunteer worker for the [[United States|American]] [[YWCA USA|YWCA]], was inspired by the poem and published a poem of her own called "[[We Shall Keep the Faith]]".<ref name=DLG>{{cite news | author = | title =Moina Michael | publisher =Digital Library of Georgia/[[University of Georgia]] | date = | url =http://georgiainfo.galileo.usg.edu/mmichael.htm | accessdate=2009-02-18}}</ref> In tribute to McCrae's poem, she vowed to always wear a red remembrance poppy as a symbol of remembrance for those who fought and helped in the war.<ref name="bbc10nov06"/> At a November 1918 YWCA Overseas War Secretaries' conference, she appeared with a silk poppy pinned to her coat and distributed 25 more to those attending. She then campaigned to have the poppy adopted as a national symbol of remembrance. At a conference in 1920, the National American Legion adopted it as their official symbol of remembrance.<ref name="bbc10nov06"/> At this conference, Frenchwoman Anna E. Guérin was inspired to introduce the artificial poppies commonly used today. In 1921 she sent her poppy sellers to London, where they were adopted by [[Field Marshal (United Kingdom)|Field Marshal]] [[Douglas Haig]], a founder of the [[Royal British Legion]]. It was also adopted by veterans' groups in [[Canada]], [[Australia]] and [[New Zealand]].<ref name="bbc10nov06"/> James Fox notes that all of the countries who adopted the remembrance poppy were the "victors" of World War I.<ref name="fox"/>
==Usage==
===Commonwealth of Nations===
====Canada==== [[File:H. Piffard - The Thin Red Line - restoration.jpg|thumb|''The Thin Red Line'' by [[Harold H. Piffard]] from ''[[Canada in Khaki]]'' showing red poppies separating the war and peace]] [[File:Poppies by Benoit Aubry of Ottawa.JPG|thumb|350px|Canadian poppies]]In Canada, the poppy is the official symbol of remembrance worn during the two weeks before 11 November, having been adopted in 1921. The [[Royal Canadian Legion]], which has [[trademark]]ed the image,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.legion.ca/honour-remember/the-poppy-trademark/|title=The Royal Canadian Legion Poppy Trademark - The Royal Canadian Legion|work=The Royal Canadian Legion|accessdate=20 May 2016}}</ref> suggests that poppies be worn on the left lapel, or as near the heart as possible.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://vac-acc.gc.ca/general/sub.cfm?source=teach_resources/poppy |title=Poppy Facts - Veterans Affairs Canada |publisher=Vac-acc.gc.ca |date=1999-10-21 |accessdate=2011-02-23}}</ref>
Until 1996, poppies were made by disabled veterans in Canada, but they have since been made by a private contractor.<ref>{{cite web|author=Webmaster, Patrick Riley |url=http://www.legion.ca/Poppy/campaign_e.cfm |title=The Royal Canadian Legion |publisher=Legion.ca |date= |accessdate=2011-02-23}}</ref> The Canadian poppies consist of two pieces of moulded plastic covered with [[Flocking (texture)|flocking]] with a pin to fasten them to clothing. At first the poppies were made with a black centre. From 1980 to 2002, the centres were changed to green. Current designs are black only; this change caused confusion and controversy to those unfamiliar with the original design.<ref>http://www.rcaf-arc.forces.gc.ca/16w-16e/nr-sp/index-eng.asp?id=180</ref> In 2007, sticker versions of the poppy were made for children, the elderly, and healthcare and food industry workers.<ref>{{cite news| first = Julia| last = Skikavich| authorlink = | coauthors = | title = New sticker poppies are catching on| url = http://www.cbc.ca/canada/story/2008/11/05/poppy-stickers.html| work = | publisher = CBC News| id = | pages = | page = | date = 2008-11-05| accessdate = 2008-11-12| language = | quote = | archiveurl = | archivedate = }}</ref> {{anchor|UK}} Canada also issues a cast metal "Canada Remembers" pin featuring a gold maple leaf and two poppies, one representing the fallen and the other representing those who remained on the [[home front]].<ref>[https://docs.google.com/leaf?id=0B3nMfjn73O0gOWE2NDkxMGQtYTRjOS00ZDE0LTk5ZDMtOWRlNGRmY2U0ODY2&sort=name&layout=list&pid=0B3nMfjn73O0gYzNkZGFiODktYTA4Ny00MTAxLWFkOTgtZDE3OTQ2MDk0ZTYx&cindex=18 ''Canada Remembers Program Policy Manual''], Veterans Affairs Canada, 2009 revision</ref>
Following the installation of the [[Canadian Tomb of the Unknown Soldier|Tomb of the Unknown Soldier]] at the [[National War Memorial (Canada)|National War Memorial]] in [[Ottawa]] in 2000, where the national Remembrance service is held, a new tradition formed spontaneously as attendees laid their poppies on the tomb at the end of the service. This tradition, while not part of the official program, has become widely practised elsewhere in the country, with others leaving cut flowers, photographs, or letters to the deceased.
====Newfoundland====
Since joining Canada on April 1st., 1949, the Remembrance Poppy and [[Armistice Day]] (November 11th.) commemorations have in large measure displaced [[Newfoundland and Labrador|Newfoundland's]] own commemorative floral emblem, the [[forget-me-not]], and national commemorative [[Memorial Day (Newfoundland and Labrador)|Memorial Day]] held July 1st. each year. Although in recent years the forget-me-not has had somewhat of a resurgence<ref>http://www.thetelegram.com/News/Local/2016-06-22/article-4567810/Special-Forget-Me-Nots/1 "Special Forget-Me-Nots"</ref> in Newfoundland cultural practices surrounding the island's military deaths<ref>http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/newfoundland-labrador/forget-me-not-newfoundland-legion-beaumont-hamel-1.3360692</ref> the Remembrance Poppy is far more commonly encountered than the forget-me-not.
====Australia==== In Australia, remembrance poppies have been used since 1921 to commemorate Australian soldiers who died in war. On Remembrance Day (11 November) and [[Anzac Day]] (25 April) they are laid at war memorials, and are sold by the [[Returned and Services League of Australia]] (RSL) in return for donations.<ref>{{Cite web|title = The Red Poppy - Australian Army|url = http://www.army.gov.au/Our-history/Traditions/The-Red-Poppy|website = www.army.gov.au|accessdate = 2015-11-10}}</ref>
====New Zealand==== [[File:NZRSA remembrance poppy.jpg|thumb|200px|New Zealand remembrance poppy]]In New Zealand, remembrance poppies are most often worn on Anzac Day (25 April) to commemorate New Zealand soldiers who died in war. They are also worn on Remembrance Day, and are sold by the [[Royal New Zealand Returned and Services' Association]] (RSA) in return for donations. The RSA planned to hold its first Poppy Day appeal around the time of Armistice Day 1921, as other countries were doing. However, the ship carrying the poppies from France arrived in New Zealand too late, and so the association waited until Anzac Day 1922. This first Poppy Day appeal was a success. Most of the money raised went to needy soldiers and their families, while the rest went to the French Children's League to help relieve suffering in war-ravaged areas of northern France.
The popularity of Poppy Day grew and there were record collections during the Second World War. By 1945, 750,000 poppies were being distributed nationwide, which equated to half the population.<ref>{{Cite web|title = The red poppy - Anzac Day {{!}} NZHistory, New Zealand history online|url = http://www.nzhistory.net.nz/war/anzac-day/poppies|website = www.nzhistory.net.nz|accessdate = 2015-11-11}}</ref>
====United Kingdom==== [[File:Royal British Legion's Paper Poppy - white background.jpg|thumb|Royal British Legion poppy]] [[File:A volunteer constructs poppies at the Royal British Legion Poppy Factory, Richmond MOD 45148164.jpg|thumb|right|A volunteer makes poppies at the Royal British Legion Poppy Factory in London, where over 30 million poppies are made by a small team each year]] [[File:Remembrance Poppy an der Manchester Town Hall.JPG|thumb|Big remembrance poppy made of plastic at [[Manchester Town Hall]]]] [[File:Bluestar 574.JPG|thumb|A poppy on a bus in [[Southampton]], England (November 2008)]] In the [[United Kingdom]], remembrance poppies are sold by [[The Royal British Legion]] (RBL). This is a [[Charitable organization|charity]] providing financial, social, political and emotional support to those who have served or who are currently serving in the [[British Armed Forces]], and their dependants. They are sold on the streets by volunteers in the weeks before Remembrance Day. The remembrance poppy is the [[trademark]] of The Royal British Legion.<ref name=ipo1>{{cite web|title=EU000681452|url=http://www.ipo.gov.uk/tmcase/Results/4/EU000681452|website=IPO|publisher=Intellectual Property Office|accessdate=13 October 2014}}</ref><ref name=ipo3>{{cite web|title=EU004066271|url=http://www.ipo.gov.uk/tmcase/Results/4/EU004066271|website=IPO|publisher=Intellectual Property Office|accessdate=13 October 2014}}</ref><ref name=ipo2>{{cite web|title=EU000681452|url=http://www.ipo.gov.uk/tmowner/Owner/Results?name=British%20Legion&postcode=|website=IPO|publisher=Intellectual Property Office|accessdate=13 October 2014}}</ref> The RBL state, "The red poppy is our [[trademark|registered mark]] and its only lawful use is to raise funds for the Poppy Appeal";<ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-wiltshire-15654558 "Wiltshire woman's poppy teardrop 'violates trademark'"]. BBC News, 9 November 2011. Retrieved 10 November 2012.</ref> its yearly fundraising drive in the weeks before Remembrance Day. The RBL says these poppies are "worn to commemorate the sacrifices of our Armed Forces and to show support to those still serving today".<ref>[http://www.britishlegion.org.uk/get-involved/poppy-appeal Poppy Appeal 2014 - The Royal British Legion website]. Retrieved 4 November 2014.</ref> Other poppy merchandise is sold throughout the year as part of the ongoing fundraising.<ref name=poppyshop>{{cite web|title=Poppy Shop|url=http://www.poppyshop.org.uk/|website=The Poppy Shop|publisher=RBL|accessdate=13 October 2014}}</ref>
In [[England]], [[Wales]], and [[Northern Ireland]], the poppies typically have two red paper petals mounted on a green plastic stem with a single green paper leaf and a prominent black plastic central boss. The stem has an additional branch used to anchor the poppy via a pin in the lapel or buttonhole. In [[Scotland]], the poppies are curled and have four petals with no leaf. The yearly selling of poppies is a major source of income for the RBL in the UK. The poppy has no fixed price; it is sold for a donation or the price may be suggested by the seller. The black plastic center of the poppy was marked "[[Haig Fund]]" until 1994 but is now marked "Poppy Appeal".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ppu.org.uk/whitepoppy/index.html |title=White Poppies For Peace |publisher=Ppu.org.uk |date= |accessdate=2011-02-23}}</ref> A team of about 50 people—most of them disabled former British military personnel—work all year round to make millions of poppies at the [[Poppy Factory]] in [[Richmond, London|Richmond]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.poppyfactory.org/|title=The Royal British Legion Poppy Factory|publisher=The Royal British Legion|accessdate=2009-11-11}}</ref> Scottish poppies are made in the [[Lady Haig's Poppy Factory]] in Edinburgh.
For many years after World War I, poppies were worn only on Remembrance Day itself.<ref name="Letters to the Daily Telegraph">{{cite news| url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/comment/letters/3634134/Letters-to-the-Daily-Telegraph.html | location=London | work=The Daily Telegraph | title=Letters to the Daily Telegraph | date=2006-11-11}}</ref> However, today the RBL's "Poppy Appeal" has a higher profile than any other charity appeal in the UK.<ref name="Letters to the Daily Telegraph"/> The poppies are widespread from late October until mid-November every year and are worn by the general public, politicians, the Royal Family and other public figures. It has become common to see large poppies on buses, tube trains and aeroplanes as well as on lampposts, billboards, public buildings and landmarks. Many newspapers and magazines show a poppy on their cover page, and some [[Social network service|social network]] users add poppies to their [[avatar (computing)|avatar]]s.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://twibbon.com/join/Royal-British-Legion-2|title=Search for a Campaign - Twibbon|work=Twibbon|accessdate=20 May 2016}}</ref> Each year, an official Poppy Appeal [[Single (music)|single]] has been released.<ref name=jossstone>[http://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/music/news/joss-stone-criticised-over-sentimentalising-famed-anti-war-song-for-poppy-appeal-9847312.html "Joss Stone criticised for sentimentalising famed anti-war song for Poppy Appeal"]. [[The Independent]]. 10 November 2014.</ref> Celebrities have begun wearing expensive crystal-clad poppy brooches, or 'bling poppies', which are sold by the RBL.<ref name=kleshna1>[http://www.dailymail.co.uk/femail/article-2059356/Kleshna-poppies-How-company-giving-10-sales-British-Legion.html "The great poppy con: How one company selling the little red flowers only gives 10% to the British Legion"]. ''[[The Daily Mail]]'', 10 November 2011.</ref> There are thousands of poppy sellers on the streets and numerous fundraising events; such as concerts, fairs, marathons and competitions. There are also many other events to raise awareness. For example, in 2011, a Second World War plane dropped 6,000 poppies over the town of [[Yeovil]] in [[Somerset]].<ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-somerset-15507929 "WWII plane drops poppies over Yeovil"]. BBC News. 29 October 2011.</ref> In 2014, the dry [[moat]] of the [[Tower of London]] was [[Blood Swept Lands and Seas of Red|covered with 888,246 ceramic poppies]] – one for each soldier of the British Empire killed in World War I.
In recent years, there has been growing controversy over the Poppy Appeal. Some—including British Army veterans—have argued that the Poppy Appeal has become excessive and garish, that it is being used to marshal support behind British military campaigns, and that poppy wearing has become compulsory for public figures.<ref name=poppyveterans>[http://www.theguardian.com/uk/2010/nov/05/poppy-appeal-subverted-veterans-complain "Poppy appeal's original aims being subverted, veterans complain"]. [[The Guardian]]. 5 November 2010.</ref><ref name=harrysmith>[http://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2013/nov/08/poppy-last-time-remembrance-harry-leslie-smith "This year, I will wear a poppy for the last time"]. [[The Guardian]]. 8 November 2013.</ref> [[Channel 4]] newsreader [[Jon Snow (journalist)|Jon Snow]] described it as "poppy fascism".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1533751/I-wont-bow-to-poppy-fascists-says-Jon-Snow.html|title=I won't bow to poppy fascists, says Jon Snow|last=Pook|first=Sally|date=10 November 2006|publisher=[[Daily Telegraph]]|accessdate=2009-11-05 | location=London}}</ref> Columnist Dan O'Neill wrote that "presenters and politicians seem to compete in a race to be first – poppies start sprouting in mid-October while the absence of a poppy is interpreted as absence of concern for the war dead, almost as an unpatriotic act of treachery".<ref name=danoneill1>[http://www.walesonline.co.uk/news/columnists/2011/11/09/dan-o-neill-s-outrage-as-politicians-send-more-to-war-while-they-wear-poppies-91466-29743917/ "Dan O’Neill's outrage as 'politicians send more to war while they wear poppies'"]. Wales Online, 9 November 2011.</ref> Likewise, Jonathan Bartley of the religious think-tank [[Ekklesia (think tank)|Ekklesia]] said "public figures in Britain are urged, indeed in many cases, required, to wear ... the red poppy, almost as an article of faith. There is a [[political correctness]] about the red poppy".<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1533752/A-time-to-remember-but-should-we-wear-a-more-Christian-white-poppy-or-a-PC-red.html |title=A time to remember, but should we wear a more 'Christian' white poppy or a 'PC' red? |last=Petre|first=Jonathan|date=10 November 2006|publisher=[[Daily Telegraph]] |accessdate=2011-11-11 |location=London}}</ref> Journalist [[Robert Fisk]] complained that the poppy has become a seasonal "fashion accessory" and that people were "ostentatiously wearing a poppy for social or work-related reasons, to look patriotic when it suited them".<ref>Fisk, Robert. [http://www.independent.ie/opinion/analysis/blood-spilled-in-war-is-now-a-fashion-accessory-2926554.html "Blood spilled in war is now a fashion accessory"]. ''[[Irish Independent]]''. 5 November 2011.</ref>Some [[Far-right politics in the United Kingdom|far-right]] groups have used the poppy as a symbol of militant [[British nationalism]], while some Muslims have begun to reject it as a symbol of Western imperialism.<ref name="fox"/>
In 1997 and again in 2000 the Royal British Legion registered the Poppy under Intellectual Property Rights (1997 Case EU000557058)<ref>75</ref> and Trade Mark (2000 Trade Mark 2239583).<ref>76</ref>
=====Northern Ireland===== The Royal British Legion also holds a yearly poppy appeal in [[Northern Ireland]] and in 2009 raised more than £1m.<ref>[http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/breaking-news/uk-ireland/poppy-appeal-in-northern-ireland-breaks-pound1m-barrier-14609389.html#ixzz1EskRCxsA "Poppy Appeal in Northern Ireland breaks £1m barrier"]. ''[[Belfast Telegraph]]''. 23 December 2009.</ref> However, the wearing of poppies in Northern Ireland is controversial.<ref name="fox"/> It is seen by many as a political symbol<ref name="fox"/><ref name=BT1>{{cite news |url=http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/local-national/thousands-gather-to-remember-war-dead-14555647.html |title=Thousands gather to remember war dead |publisher=Belfast Telegraph |date=7 November 2009}}</ref> and a symbol of [[Britishness]],<ref name="fox"/><ref name=cainsymbols>[http://cain.ulst.ac.uk/images/symbols/unionloyal.htm Symbols used in Northern Ireland: Unionist and loyalist symbols]. [[Conflict Archive on the Internet]] (CAIN).</ref><ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/25480.stm "Adams apologises for Enniskillen bombing"]. BBC News, 8 November 1997.</ref> representing support for the British Army.<ref name=BT1/> The poppy has long been the preserve of the [[Unionism in Ireland|unionist]]/[[Ulster loyalism|loyalist]] community.<ref name="fox"/><ref name=cainsymbols/> Loyalist paramilitaries (such as the [[Ulster Volunteer Force|UVF]] and [[Ulster Defence Association|UDA]]) have also used poppies to commemorate their own members who were killed in [[The Troubles]].<ref>Bort, Eberhard. ''Commemorating Ireland: History, politics, culture''. Irish Academic Press, 2004. p.65</ref>
Most [[Irish nationalism|Irish nationalists]]/[[Irish republicanism|republicans]], and Irish Catholics, choose not to wear poppies;<ref name=BT1/> they regard the Poppy Appeal as supporting soldiers who killed Irish civilians (for example on [[Bloody Sunday (1972)|Bloody Sunday]]) and who [[Operation Banner#Collusion with loyalist paramilitaries|colluded]] with illegal [[Ulster loyalism#Paramilitary and vigilante groups|loyalist paramilitaries]] (for example the [[Glenanne gang]]) during The Troubles.<ref name="fox"/><ref>[http://www.derryjournal.com/community/columnists/maybe_it_s_time_for_a_green_poppy_instead_1_2117641 "Maybe it's time for a green poppy instead"]. ''[[Derry Journal]]''. 12 November 2007.</ref><ref name="andersonstown">[http://www.belfastmedia.com/news_article.php?ID=2242 "PSNI wearing poppies in West Belfast for political reasons: RFJ"]. ''[[Andersonstown News]]''. 28 October 2008.</ref><ref name="westtyronesf">[http://www.westtyronesinnfein.com/news/15040 "BBC's Poppy Wearing Policy Offensive to Majority of Nationalists and Republicans"]. West Tyrone Sinn Féin. 11 November 2009.</ref><ref name="irishind">[http://www.independent.ie/opinion/letters/lest-we-forget-who-they-honour-1218939.html "Lest we forget who they honour"]. ''[[Irish Independent]]''. 14 November 2007.</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/northern_ireland/502290.stm | work=BBC News | title=Westlife poppy backing 'not their decision' | date=2 November 1999}}</ref> Irish nationalist groups, and victims' groups, have urged the BBC to end its policy that all presenters must wear poppies. They argue that it [[Journalism ethics and standards|breaches impartiality]] and point out that political symbols are banned in workplaces in Northern Ireland. They also say that the BBC, as a publicly funded body, should broadly reflect the whole community.<ref name="westtyronesf"/><ref>[http://www.newsletter.co.uk/news/bbc-presenters-should-be-banned-from-wearning-poppies-1-7042455 "BBC presenters should be banned from wearning poppies"]. [[The News Letter]]. 1 November 2015.</ref> Likewise, the director of [[Relatives for Justice]] has condemned the wearing of poppies by [[Police Service of Northern Ireland|police officers]] in Catholic neighbourhoods, calling it "repugnant and offensive to the vast majority of people within our community, given the [[Operation Banner#Controversies|role of the British Army]]".<ref name="andersonstown"/> In the ''[[Irish Independent]]'', it was claimed that "substantial amounts" of money raised from selling poppies are used "to build monuments to insane or inane generals or build old boys' clubs for the war elite".<ref name="irishind"/> However, on Remembrance Day 2010 the [[Social Democratic and Labour Party|SDLP]]’s [[Margaret Ritchie (politician)|Margaret Ritchie]] was the first leader of a nationalist party to wear one.<ref>[http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/local-national/northern-ireland/ritchie-poppy-is-act-of-moving-on-15003906.html "Poppy is Act of Moving On"]. ''[[Belfast Telegraph]]''.</ref>
===Republic of Ireland=== During World War I, all of [[Ireland]] was part of the United Kingdom and about 200,000 Irishmen fought in the British Army (see [[Ireland and World War I]]). Although the British Army is banned from actively recruiting in the [[Republic of Ireland]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/1954/en/act/pub/0018/print.html |title=Defence Act, 1954 |publisher=Irishstatutebook.ie |date=1954-05-13 |accessdate=2011-02-23}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.anphoblacht.com/news/detail/39792 |title=Taxpayers' money used for British Army recruitment in Limerick |publisher=An Phoblacht |date= |accessdate=2011-02-23}}</ref> a small number of its citizens still enlist.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/local-national/north-and-south-of-ireland-fighting-the-taliban-together-13922458.html | title=North and South of Ireland fighting the Taliban together | accessdate=11 May 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Bootcamp Ireland |url=http://www.independent.ie/national-news/irish-soldier-killed-in-bomb-blast-told-of-afghan-fears-1470617.html |title=Irish soldier killed in bomb blast told of Afghan fears - National News, Frontpage |publisher=Independent.ie |date= 6 September 2008|accessdate=2011-02-23}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Self-catering |url=http://www.independent.ie/lifestyle/jobs-careers/the-irish-recruits-who-fight-for-queen-and-country-1502910.html |title=The Irish recruits who fight for Queen and country - Jobs & Careers, Lifestyle |publisher=Independent.ie |date= 18 October 2008|accessdate=2011-02-23}}</ref> The RBL thus has a branch in the Republic and holds a yearly Poppy Appeal there. The RBL also holds a wreath-laying ceremony at [[St Patrick's Cathedral, Dublin]], which the [[President of Ireland]] has attended.<ref>[http://www.newsletter.co.uk/news/local/republic_gets_behind_poppy_appeal_1_1873137 "Republic gets behind Poppy Appeal"]. ''[[The News Letter]]''. 29 July 2008.</ref>
The Republic has its own [[National Day of Commemoration]] in July for all Irish people who died in war. However, wearing poppies is not common and they are not part of the main commemorations.<ref>[http://www.thejournal.ie/readme/column-is-it-time-to-start-wearing-the-poppy-275814-Nov2011/ Column: Is it time to start wearing the poppy?]. [[TheJournal.ie]]. 10 November 2011.</ref><ref>[http://www.independent.ie/irish-news/government-defend-taoiseach-decision-not-to-wear-poppy-28895378.html "Government defends Taoiseach decision not to wear poppy"]. ''[[Irish Independent]]'', 12 November 2012.</ref> This is partly due to the British Army's role in fighting against Irish independence, its activities during the [[Irish War of Independence|War of Independence]] (for example the [[Burning of Cork]])<ref>[http://www.nga.ie/news-press_release-Wearing_of_the_British_Poppy.php Wearing of the British poppy]. [[National Graves Association]].</ref> and the British Army's role in Northern Ireland during [[the Troubles]].
In the years following the War of Independence, the poppy was particularly controversial, with nationalists seeing it as a provocative symbol of British imperialism. In Dublin, British Legion marchers often had poppies snatched from their lapels, which led to street fights. In response, some poppy-wearers hid razor blades in their poppies.<ref>McGarry, Fearghal. ''Republicanism in Modern Ireland''. University College Dublin Press, 2003. p.66</ref><ref>Martin Evans & Kenneth Lunn. ''War and Memory in the Twentieth Century''. Bloomsbury Academic, 1997. p.66</ref> "As the 1930s progressed, 'Poppy Day' lost much of its violent edge in Dublin, but the wearing of the symbol also became less commonplace in subsequent decades".<ref>[http://comeheretome.com/2015/11/04/poppy-snatching-in-dublin/ "Poppy-snatching in Dublin"]. ''Come Here to Me – Dublin life and culture''. 4 November 2015.</ref>
===Elsewhere=== In the [[United States]], the [[Veterans of Foreign Wars]] conducted the first nationwide distribution of remembrance poppies before [[Memorial Day]] in 1922.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vfw.org/Community/Buddy-Poppy/|title=VFW Buddy Poppy Program - In Flander' s Field Poem by John McCrae|publisher=|accessdate=20 May 2016}}</ref> Today, the [[American Legion Auxiliary]] distributes crepe-paper poppies in exchange for donations around [[Memorial Day]] and [[Veterans Day]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.legion-aux.org/Programs/Poppy/|title=Login|author=American Legion Auxiliary|publisher=|accessdate=20 May 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.legion.org/troops/216371/legion-family-flower-remembrance|title=Legion Family flower of remembrance|work=The American Legion|accessdate=20 May 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Office of Public and Intergovernmental Affairs |url=http://www1.va.gov/opa/vetsday/vetday_faq.asp |title=Veterans Day Frequently Asked Questions - Office of Public and Intergovernmental Affairs |publisher=.va.gov |date=2009-11-10 |accessdate=2011-02-23}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.legion.org/troops/216371/legion-family-flower-remembrance |title=distribution of poppies is prominent around Memorial Day and Veterans Day |publisher=American Legion |date= |accessdate=2013-10-03}}</ref>
In [[Hong Kong]]—which was formerly part of the British Empire—the poppy is worn by some participants on Remembrance Sunday each year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.scmp.com/topics/remembrance-day|title=Remembrance Day|work=South China Morning Post|accessdate=20 May 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hkesa.com.hk/Events%20&%20Activities.php#remembranceDay|title=HKESA Home Page|publisher=|accessdate=20 May 2016}}</ref> It is not generally worn by the public, although The Royal British Legion's Hong Kong and China Branch sells poppies to the public in a few places in Hong Kong only.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://branches.britishlegion.org.uk/branches/hong-kong/poppy-appeal|title=The Poppy Appeal in Hong Kong - Hong Kong & China Branch - The Royal British Legion.|publisher=|accessdate=20 May 2016}}</ref>
[[File:Ніколи Знову 02.svg|thumbnail|Never Again symbol from [[Ukraine]]]] During [[Victory Day (9 May)|Victory Day]] 2014—which marks Nazi Germany's surrender to the Soviet Union—some [[Ukraine|Ukrainians]] wore remembrance poppies instead of the usual [[Ribbon of Saint George]], as the ribbon had become associated with [[2014 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine|pro-Russian separatists]]. A poppy logo was designed by Sergiy Mishakin, containing the text: "1939-1945 Never Again".<ref>[http://www.forbes.com/sites/realspin/2014/05/14/poppies-vs-ribbons-the-war-of-symbols-between-ukraine-and-russia/ "Poppies Vs. Ribbons: The War Of Symbols Between Ukraine And Russia"]. ''Forbes''. 14 May 2014.</ref>
In parts of [[Pakistan]], the 'Great War Company' hold a private ceremony each 11 November where red poppies are worn, by descendants of World War I veterans from the old [[British Indian Army]].<ref>Asim Ghani, article, 'Auld lang syne?--shall they be never forgotten indeed?' , in the ''Pakistan Observer'', Islamabad, Monday, 18th November 2013</ref>
In [[Albania]], government representatives, including Prime Minister [[Edi Rama]], wore the Remembrance Poppy during the commemoration ceremonies for the 70th Anniversary of the Liberation of Albania.<ref>[http://www.shekulli.com.al/web/p.php?id=61467&kat=88 "70-vjetori i Çlirimit/ Krerët e Shtetit, homazhe te Varrezat e Dëshmorëve (FOTO)"]. ''Shekulli''. 29th November 2014</ref>
==Other designs and purposes==
===White poppies=== [[File:Anzac poppies.JPG|thumb|A white poppy left on [[Anzac Day]] in New Zealand, 2009]] Some people choose to wear [[White poppy (symbol)|white poppies]] as a [[pacifism|pacifist]] alternative to the red poppy. The white poppy and white poppy wreaths were introduced by Britain's [[Co-operative Women's Guild]] in 1933.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ppu.org.uk/whitepoppy/white_cwg.html |title=White Poppies For Peace |publisher=[[Peace Pledge Union]] |date=1938-11-11 |accessdate=2011-02-23}}</ref> Today, white poppies are sold by [[Peace Pledge Union]] or may be home-made.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ppu.org.uk/whitepoppy/index.html |title=White Poppies Are For Peace |publisher=Peace Pledge Union |date= |accessdate=2011-02-23}}</ref> The white poppy may be worn alone or alongside the red poppy. According to the Peace Pledge Union, it symbolizes remembrance of all casualties of war including civilian casualties, and non-British casualties, to stand for peace, and not to glamorize war.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ppu.org.uk/whitepoppy/index.html}}</ref>
===Purple poppies=== To commemorate animal victims of war, [[Animal Aid]] in Britain has issued a purple poppy, which can be worn alongside the traditional red one, as a reminder that both humans and animals have been – and continue to be – victims of war.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.animalaid.org.uk/h/n/CAMPAIGNS/living//2256/|title=PURPLE POPPY: COMMEMORATING THE ANIMAL VICTIMS OF WAR|accessdate=October 31, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/8333733.stm|title= The dos and don'ts of poppy etiquette|publisher=BBC|accessdate=28 October 2013|date=30 October 2009}}</ref> Recently, the purple poppy was abolished due to a perceived misunderstanding by the issuing organization. It was replaced by a purple paw symbol that can be worn all year round.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.animalaid.org.uk/h/n/CAMPAIGNS/living//3329/|title=Animal Aid|publisher=|accessdate=20 May 2016}}</ref>
==Protests and controversy== In 1993, The Royal British Legion complained that ''[[Cannon Fodder (video game)|Cannon Fodder]]'', a video game with an anti-war message, had planned to use a poppy on its cover. The Legion, along with some politicians, called it "offensive to millions" and "monstrous". The publisher was forced to change the cover before the game was released.
In 2010 a group of British Army veterans issued an open letter complaining that the Poppy Appeal had become excessive and garish, that it was being used to marshal support behind British military campaigns, and that people were being pressured into wearing poppies.<ref name=poppyveterans/> In 2014, the group protested by holding an alternative remembrance service: they walked to [[The Cenotaph, Whitehall|The Cenotaph]] under the banner "Never Again" with a wreath of white poppies to acknowledge civilians killed in war. Their tops bore the message "War is Organised Murder", a quote from [[Harry Patch]], the last survivor of World War I.<ref>[http://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/never-again-anti-war-veterans-to-carry-white-poppy-wreath-to-cenotaph-9833246.html "'Never again': Anti-war veterans to carry white-poppy wreath to Cenotaph"]. [[The Independent]]. 2 November 2014.</ref><ref>[http://veteransforpeace.org.uk/2014/war-weary-veterans-hold-aternative-remembrance-sunday-event/ "War-Weary Veterans Hold Aternative Remembrance Sunday Event"]. Veterans For Peace. 11 November 2014.</ref> [[File:Celtic team - November 2010.jpg|thumb|right|Football clubs commonly wear jerseys with a poppy emblazoned on, as [[Celtic F.C.|Celtic]] controversially did in 2010.]] In the run-up to Remembrance Day, it has become common for UK [[Association football|football]] teams to play with artificial poppies sewn to their shirts, at the request of the Royal British Legion. This has caused some controversy. At a [[Celtic F.C.|Celtic]] v [[Aberdeen F.C.|Aberdeen]] match in November 2010, a group of Celtic supporters, called the [[Green Brigade]], unfurled a large banner in protest at the team wearing poppies. In a statement, it said: "Our group and many within the Celtic support do not recognise the British Armed Forces as heroes, nor their role in many conflicts as one worthy of our remembrance". It gave [[Operation Banner]] (Northern Ireland), the [[War in Afghanistan (2001–present)|Afghanistan War]] and the [[Iraq War]] as examples.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.etims.net/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=3038&Itemid=29 |title=Green Brigade Statement on the Poppy Protest |date=9 November 2010 |publisher=E-Tims Online Fanzine |accessdate=5 January 2011}}</ref> In November 2011, it was proposed that the [[England national football team|England football team]] should wear poppies on their shirts in a match against [[Spain national football team|Spain]]. However, [[FIFA]] turned down the proposal, saying it would "open the door to similar initiatives" across the world, "jeopardising the neutrality of football".<ref name=dailymail-fifa-2011>[http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-2059467/FIFA-poppy-ban-David-Cameron-happy-defy-ban.html "Cameron gives England players green light to defy FIFA ruling on poppies for Wembley clash"]. ''[[The Daily Mail]]'', 9 November 2011.</ref> FIFA's decision was attacked by [[Prince William, Duke of Cambridge|Prince William]]<ref name=guardian-fifa-2011>[http://www.guardian.co.uk/football/2011/nov/09/david-cameron-outrageous-poppy-ban?newsfeed=true "Prince William calls on FIFA to overturn ban on England shirt poppies"]. ''[[The Guardian]]'', 9 November 2011.</ref> and Prime Minister [[David Cameron]], who said he would back any player who ignored the ban.<ref name=dailymail-fifa-2011/> Members of the [[English Defence League]] (EDL) held a protest on the roof of FIFA's headquarters in [[Zürich]].<ref name=dailymirror-fifa-2011>[http://www.mirrorfootball.co.uk/news/English-Defence-League-protesters-target-FIFA-over-poppy-ban-article828782.html "EDL protesters occupy FIFA's roof over poppy ban"]. ''[[The Daily Mirror]]'', 9 November 2011.</ref> Instead, [[The Football Association]] came up with other ways to mark Remembrance Day; for example, the England players would wear poppies before kickoff and black armbands during the match, there would be a minute's silence, a poppy wreath would be set on the pitch during the national anthems, poppies would be sold in the stadium and would be shown on the scoreboards and advertising boards.<ref name=dailymail-fifa-2011/> FIFA subsequently allowed the English, Scottish and Welsh teams to wear poppies on black armbands.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/15666769.stm "FIFA allows England, Scotland and Wales to wear poppy"], [[BBC News]], 9 November 2011. Accessed 12 November 2011.</ref> Northern Irish-born footballer [[James McClean]], who has played for a number of English teams, has received [[death threat]]s and abuse since 2012 for refusing to wear a poppy on his shirt during matches.<ref>[http://www.theguardian.com/football/2012/nov/18/sunderland-james-mcclean-death-threat 'Sunderland's James McClean receives death threat over poppy protest']</ref> McClean is from the neighbourhood of Derry, [[County Londonderry]] where British soldiers shot dead 14 unarmed civilians on [[Bloody Sunday (1972)|Bloody Sunday]].<ref>[http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/local-national/northern-ireland/wigan-player-james-mcclean-explains-why-he-will-not-wear-a-poppy-30730556.html "Wigan player James McClean explains why he will not wear a poppy"]. ''Belfast Telegraph''. 10 November 2014.</ref>
Other public figures have also been attacked for not wearing poppies. British journalist and newsreader [[Charlene White]] has faced racist and sexist abuse for not wearing a poppy on-screen. She explained "I prefer to be neutral and impartial on screen so that one of those charities doesn't feel less favoured than another".<ref>Shane Hickey [http://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2013/nov/13/charlene-white-itv-news-presenter-remembrance-day-poppy "ITV news presenter hits back after abuse for not wearing poppy"], theguardian.com, 13 November 2013</ref> Newsreader [[Jon Snow (journalist)|Jon Snow]] does not wear a poppy on-screen for similar reasons. He too was criticized and he condemned what he saw as "poppy fascism".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.standard.co.uk/news/newsreader-jon-snow-rails-against-poppy-fascism-7263001.html|title=Newsreader Jon Snow rails against 'poppy fascism'|date=9 November 2006|work=Evening Standard|accessdate=20 May 2016}}</ref> Well-known war-time journalist [[Robert Fisk]] published in November 2011 a personal account about the shifting nature of wearing a poppy, titled "Do those who flaunt the poppy on their lapels know that they mock the war dead?".<ref>[http://www.independent.co.uk/voices/commentators/fisk/robert-fisk-do-those-who-flaunt-the-poppy-on-their-lapels-know-that-they-mock-the-war-dead-6257416.html "Do those who flaunt the poppy on their lapels know that they mock the war dead?"]. [[The Independent]]. Accessed 4 November 2014.</ref> While all newsreaders in the UK are expected to wear the remembrance poppy, those on the [[BBC World News|BBC's international news]] service are told not to. The BBC say this is because the symbol is not widely recognized overseas. The Royal British Legion condemned this, insisting that the poppy is the "international symbol of remembrance".<ref>[http://www.scotsman.com/news/uk/mp-s-fury-at-bbc-ban-on-poppies-1-584905 "MP’s fury at BBC ban on poppies"]. ''The Scotsman''. 3 November 2001.</ref>
[[File:Stormtrooper with a remembrance poppy - stencil (2016).jpg|thumb|[[Stencil graffiti]] of a [[Stormtrooper (Star Wars)|Stormtrooper]] with a remembrance poppy (London, 2016)]] British Prime Minister David Cameron rejected a request from [[China|Chinese]] officials to remove his poppy during his visit to [[Beijing]] on Remembrance Day 2010. The poppy was deemed offensive because it was mistakenly assumed to be connected with the Anglo-Chinese Opium Wars in the 19th century, after which the [[Qing Dynasty]] was forced to tolerate the British [[History of opium in China|opium trade]] in China and to cede [[Hong Kong]] to the UK.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2010-11-09/cameron-risks-spat-with-chinese-by-wearing-poppy-during-visit-to-beijing.html|title=Cameron Risks Spat With Chinese by Wearing Poppy During Visit |date=9 November 2010 |publisher=Bloomberg LP |accessdate=12 November 2011 |first=Robert |last=Hutton}}</ref> However, Cameron wore a poppy in 2015 when he met Chinese President [[Xi Jinping]] in London.
A 2010 Remembrance Day ceremony in London was disrupted by members of [[Muslims Against Crusades]], who were protesting against British Army actions in Afghanistan and Iraq. They burnt large poppies and chanted "British soldiers burn in hell" during the two-minute silence. Two of the men were arrested and charged for threatening behaviour. One was convicted and fined £50.<ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-12664346 "Man guilty of burning poppies at Armistice Day protest"]. BBC News. 7 March 2011.</ref> The same group planned to hold another protest in 2011,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.youtube.com/user/izharudeen#p/a/u/0/sJg9wHsEiEU |title=Interview with convicted terrorist Abu Izzadeen about 'Hell for Heroes' protests |date=1 November 2011 |publisher=Izharudeen.com |accessdate=1 November 2011}}</ref><ref>[http://www.mirror.co.uk/news/top-stories/2011/10/31/extreme-muslim-group-planning-remembrance-day-protest-115875-23526745/] Daily Mirror</ref> but was banned by the [[Home Secretary]] the day before the planned protest.<ref>{{cite news|last=Casciani|first=Dominic|title=Muslims Against Crusades banned by Theresa May|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-15678275|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=11 November 2011|date=10 November 2011}}</ref> In 2014, a campaign was begun to encourage Muslim women to wear poppy [[hijab]]s. Some criticized it as a "shrouded loyalty test" which implied that Muslims needed to prove their loyalty to Britain.<ref>Allen, Chris. [http://www.newstatesman.com/politics/2014/11/poppy-hijab-just-islamophobia-floral-motif "The poppy hijab is just Islamophobia with a floral motif"]. [[New Statesman]]. 3 November 2014.</ref><ref>[http://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/features/2014/11/split-uk-opinion-over-poppy-hijabs-20141196523894487.html "Split UK opinion over 'poppy hijabs'"]. [[Al Jazeera]]. 9 November 2014.</ref><ref>[http://edition.cnn.com/2014/10/31/world/europe/poppy-hijab-controversy/ "Poppy hijab honors Muslims, sparks controversy"]. CNN. 1 November 2014.</ref>
In recent years, people have been arrested in the UK for burning remembrance poppies. In November 2011 a number of people were arrested in Northern Ireland after a picture of two youths burning a poppy was posted on [[Facebook]]. The picture was reported to police by a member of the RBL.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/uk/2011/nov/03/poppy-burning-northern-ireland-arrests?newsfeed=true | location=London | work=The Guardian | first=Henry | last=McDonald | title=Poppy-burning image leads to Northern Ireland arrests | date=3 November 2011}}</ref> The following year, a young [[Canterbury]] man was arrested for allegedly posting a picture of a burning poppy on Facebook, on suspicion of an offence under the Malicious Communications Act.<ref>{{cite news|last=Rawlinson|first=Kevin|title='Poppycock': Man's arrest for posting image of burning poppy on Facebook is condemned by civil liberties activists|url=http://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/crime/poppycock-mans-arrest-for-posting-image-of-burning-poppy-on-facebook-is-condemned-by-civil-liberties-activists-8306784.html|publisher=Independent.co.uk|accessdate=4 February 2013|location=London|date=12 November 2012}}</ref>
In 2011 it was revealed that Kleshna, one of two businesses selling its own poppies on the RBL website, gives only 10% of its sales to charity. Kleshna sells crystal-clad poppy jewellery which has been worn by celebrities on television.<ref name=kleshna1/>
